title: What Stefon Diggs said about his Patriots future
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Stefon Diggs plans to stay with the Patriots next season, though he acknowledges the decision isn't entirely his.
Diggs signed a three-year, $69 million contract with the Patriots last offseason, valid through the 2027 season.
Diggs faces a court date for assault and strangulation charges but has denied the allegations, with Patriots' support.

title: Prosecutor who tried Brian Walshe for murder enters Norfolk DA race
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Greg Connor, Norfolk County prosecutor, enters race for District Attorney following his success in Brian Walshe murder trial.
Connor files for candidacy as current Norfolk DA Michael Morrissey will not seek reelection, creating an open field of candidates.
Connor emphasizes his 25 years' experience in Norfolk County's legal system and critiques past case handling for needed reforms.

title: Red Sox land Caleb Durbin in six-player trade with Brewers
author: Samantha Genzer
bullets: Red Sox acquire third baseman Caleb Durbin in a six-player trade with the Brewers, including a competitive draft pick.
Boston also receives infielder Andruw Monasterio and catcher Anthony Seigler, sending three players to Milwaukee.
Durbin, a top NL rookie in 2025, batted .256 with 11 home runs and 18 stolen bases in 136 games.

title: Former Jets player charged with killing woman from Framingham
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Former Jets player Darron Lee charged with first-degree murder of Gabriella Perpetuo in Ooltewah, Tennessee.
Lee was arrested on Feb. 5; authorities report blood and signs of struggle throughout the residence.
Perpetuo's family initiated a GoFundMe raising over $53,000 for funeral and legal expenses.

title: World Cup plans at risk as Foxborough pushes for security funding
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Foxborough officials are withholding Gillette Stadium's entertainment license unless $7.7 million is secured for police and safety operations.
Massachusetts is set to receive over $47 million in federal funds, but Foxborough seeks full upfront payment from event organizers.
A March 17 deadline is set for resolving funding issues; discussions involve FIFA, the Kraft Group, and local authorities.

title: Marlborough hospital evacuated after ‘Code Black’ shutdown
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: UMass Memorial's Marlborough campus evacuated over 70 patients after heat and water systems failed due to a valve break.
The hospital declared 'Code Black', stopping new emergency arrivals and transferring patients to other hospitals in the system.
Marlborough Campus remains closed for inpatient services, only offering mammography among outpatient services, amid ongoing mitigation.

title: Patriots rookie Kyle Williams chased down a streaker at Super Bowl LX
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Patriots rookie Kyle Williams stopped a streaker during the fourth quarter of Super Bowl LX with a quick chase.
The streaker was arrested by Santa Clara Police on suspicion of trespassing and field intrusion charges.
Williams, a third-round pick, recorded a 4.40-second 40-yard dash at the 2025 NFL Scouting Combine.

title: Offseason primer: Here’s a quick look at Patriots’ list of 2026 draft picks, pending free agents
author: Hayden Bird
bullets: The Patriots hold 11 picks in the 2026 NFL Draft, positioning them well for team improvements.
New England Patriots have over $42 million in cap space, providing flexibility for offseason moves.
Key potential free agents include Austin Hooper, K’Lavon Chaisson, and Khyiris Tonga among others.

title: Federal judge who said he retired to fight Trump was reportedly subject of misconduct probe
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Judge Mark L. Wolf resigned amid allegations of creating a hostile work environment, triggering a judicial inquiry.
Chief Circuit Judge David Barron found probable cause of misconduct, including interviews with the judge and a former clerk.
Wolf, a Reagan appointee, resigned reportedly to oppose the Trump administration and took a role at Todd & Weld.

title: Local obituary: Accursio ‘Gus’ Sanfilippo, 55, Gloucester fisherman and captain of the Lily Jean
author: Boston.com Staff
bullets: Accursio 'Gus' Sanfilippo, a 55-year-old Gloucester fisherman, passed away at sea on January 30, 2026.
Captain of the Lily Jean and a dory racing enthusiast, Sanfilippo leaves behind his wife Lorie and two children.
Visitation will be held at Greely Funeral Home, Gloucester, on February 9 followed by a funeral mass on February 10.
